ok, in that case -- add the user name you log into ssh with on the remote box to the www-data group (on the remote box) :)

the www-data group has read/write access in that folder - if your user is a member of that group, you get those priveleges too
this is pretty much like windows user administration (infact micrsoft copied and enhanced the unix permissions model)

when you use 'Connect to Server' .. the remote machine uses the credentials you supply there .. therefore, the permissions you view later are for that user

it's like this -- you setup a server, can a remote user connecting to it, use his own username and password (that he setup on his box), no.. he has to be authenticated by your server

774 is what you want (rwxrwxr--) .. that makes the user have read/write access, the group read/write and others just read

when you use 'Connect to Server' .. the remote machine uses the credentials you supply there .. therefore, the permissions you view later are for that user
the user that would be sittin on-the-remote-box right?
Flannel here let me try something brb
yep
it's like this -- you setup a server, can a remote user connecting to it, use his own username and password (that he setup on his box), no.. he has to be authenticated by your server
so, what did you have to change?
but didnt we already do that?
this is what i did,   sudo nautilus..  then went to the /var/www propertires, hit permissions enabled WRITE for Other users, and thats it
errm, but which permissions did you change?
group or world/other?
i just added write permissions on Other users, (but I reversed that)
i prefer you did this command -- sudo chmod -Rv 774 /var/www
the command i gave you should have done it
when I made the change manually thru the graphical interface, it changed to 774. shouldnt that be the same?
774 is what you want (rwxrwxr--) .. that makes the user have read/write access, the group read/write and others just read
its fixed
